title: Precise <italic>let-7</italic> expression levels balance organ regeneration against tumor suppression
abstract: The in vivo roles for even the most intensely studied microRNAs remain poorly defined. Here, analysis of mouse models revealed that <italic>let-7</italic>, a large and ancient microRNA family, performs tumor suppressive roles at the expense of regeneration. Too little or too much <italic>let-7</italic> resulted in compromised protection against cancer or tissue damage, respectively. Modest <italic>let-7</italic> overexpression abrogated <italic>MYC</italic>-driven liver cancer by antagonizing multiple <italic>let-7</italic> sensitive oncogenes. However, the same level of overexpression blocked liver regeneration, while <italic>let-7</italic> deletion enhanced it, demonstrating that distinct <italic>let-7</italic> levels can mediate desirable phenotypes. <italic>let-7</italic> dependent regeneration phenotypes resulted from influences on the insulin-PI3K-mTOR pathway. We found that chronic high-dose <italic>let-7</italic> overexpression caused liver damage and degeneration, paradoxically leading to tumorigenesis. These dose-dependent roles for <italic>let-7</italic> in tissue repair and tumorigenesis rationalize the tight regulation of this microRNA in development, and have important implications for <italic>let-7</italic> based therapeutics.
